episodes.title: How activist investors are changing public company boards
episodes.summary: Rotman professor and experienced board director David Beatty considers several profound changes.

episodes.title: The CFO's role in war gaming
episodes.summary: With an emphasis on analytics, CFOs are uniquely positioned to lead a war gaming excercise.

episodes.title: A closer look at the growth of M&A from China
episodes.summary: What’s behind the uptick in China M&A—and what does it mean for companies elsewhere?

episodes.title: When should companies sell off their accounts receivable?
episodes.summary: One way companies can raise immediate capital or mitigate the risk of being able to collect on their accounts receivable is to sell them off to a third party -- otherwise known as “factoring.”  What is it, how does it work, and under what circumstances should a company factor?

episodes.title: What’s changing in board governance—a conversation with Bill Huyett
episodes.summary: Board governance has changed in recent years, with transparency and visibility into the role increasing just as the pendulum swings between the demands of regulatory compliance and the strategic needs of companies. In this podcast, McKinsey’s Bill Huyett joins Werner Rehm to talk about how board governance has changed—and how CEOs and CFOs can work together to improve a company’s performance.

episodes.title: Getting better at resource re-allocation: a conversation with Yuval Atsmon
episodes.summary: Managers at most companies understand the value of re-allocating resources from unproductive investments into more productive ones, but in practice they seldom do. In this podcast, McKinsey’s Yuval Atsmon and Werner Rehm examine how managers can overcome some of the obstacles that get in the way of more nimble reallocation.  Yuval is a principal in McKinsey’s London office and Werner is an Equity Partner in the New York office.

episodes.title: M&A 2015: A conversation with Andy West
episodes.summary: M&A surged again in 2015, led by activity in the US and by large deals.  In this podcast, McKinsey’s Werner Rehm discusses what happened and why with Andy West, Andy is a leader of McKinsey’s Merger Management group, the Transactions service line of the Corporate Finance Practice, and the High Tech Practice and has authored numerous articles on value creation through M&A.  Andy is a director in McKinsey’s Boston office and Werner is an Equity Partner in the New  York office.

episodes.title: Why do some projects have higher internal rates of return?
episodes.summary: IRRs are not all created equal—and the differences between projects or funds can be material for oil and gas companies, private equity investors, or even investment funds themselves who use the metric as a shorthand benchmark for comparing diverse projects. In this podcast, McKinsey’s Werner Rehm discusses variations in IRR with Marc Goedhart and Chip Hughes.  Marc is a Senior Expert in McKinsey’s Amsterdam office and co-author of the recent article, “A better way to understand Internal Rate of Return.”  Chip is a consultant in McKinsey’s New York office, where Werner is an Equity Partner.

episodes.title: How do share buybacks affect investment in growth?
episodes.summary: Two co-authors of Valuation, McKinsey's Tim Koller and Marc Goedhart, explore what's driving the recent increase in share buybacks and dividends and the likely impact on investment in growth. Moderated by Werner Rehm.

episodes.title: What managers need to know about hedging currency risk
episodes.summary: When exchange rates are volatile, companies rush to stem potential losses by hedging their risks.  McKinsey's Tim Koller and Marc Goedhart, discuss which currency risks should be hedged--and which would be better left alone.  Moderated by Werner Rehm.

episodes.title: Divestitures: how to invest for success
episodes.summary: When it comes to creating value, divestitures are critical—but a positive outcome is not automatic. Here’s how some up-front investment can improve the odds of success.

episodes.title: Getting a better handle on currency risk
episodes.summary: When exchange rates are volatile, companies rush to stem potential losses. Which risks should they hedge — and how.

episodes.title: Why capital expenditures need more CFO attention
episodes.summary: Companies in capital-intensive industries need to get more out of their capital budgets. CFOs can play a critical role.

episodes.title: A hidden roadblock in public infrastructure projects
episodes.summary: Misplaced assumptions that governments always enjoy a cost-of-capital advantage over private players can kill projects on the drawing board. Reexamining the economics could move more deals ahead.

episodes.title: Overcoming obstacles to effective scenario planning
episodes.summary: Using scenarios to plan for uncertainty can broaden the mind but can fall prey to the mind’s inner workings. Here’s how to get more out of planning efforts.

episodes.title: M&A 2014: Return of the big deal
episodes.summary: Investors are optimistic about the value of big deals behind a growing wave of M&A. What key trends do they need to understand?

episodes.title: The real business of business
episodes.summary: Shareholder-oriented capitalism is still the best path to broad economic prosperity, as long as companies focus on the long term.

episodes.title: Maintaining a long-term view during turnarounds
episodes.summary: Changing course demands an intense focus on short-term performance, but success needn’t come at the expense of long-term value.

episodes.title: Can we talk? Five tips for communicating in turnarounds
episodes.summary: In tough times, investors scrutinize every detail. Here’s how to manage the discussion.

episodes.title: Why today’s markets are buoyant
episodes.summary: Here’s how a tepid economy and rising interest rates support a strong stock market.

episodes.title: Uncovering cash and insights from working capital
episodes.summary:
Improving a company’s management of working capital can generate cash and
improve performance far beyond the finance department. Here’s how.

episodes.title: Making trade-offs in corporate portfolio decisions
episodes.summary: Managers often want to own good businesses they shouldn’t buy—or hold onto businesses they should sell. Here’s how some companies have made these tough decisions.

episodes.title: Preparing to make big-ticket investment decisions
episodes.summary:
When the stakes couldn’t be higher, the quality of the decision making can make
all the difference. Process improvements can help.

episodes.title: Preparing for bigger, bolder shareholder activists
episodes.summary: Activists are targeting more and bigger companies. Here’s what attracts them—and some tips on how to respond when they show up.

episodes.title: Global M&A: Fewer deals, better quality
episodes.summary: In 2013, investors continued to improve their discipline in creating value.

episodes.title: Goodwill shunting: How to better manage write-downs
episodes.summary: Executives fret that writing down goodwill invites a negative market response. But that isn’t always so.

episodes.title: Avoiding blind spots in your next joint venture
episodes.summary: Even joint ventures developed using familiar best practices can fail without cross-process discipline in planning and implementation.

episodes.title: How they fell: The collapse of Chinese cross-border listings
episodes.summary: As the China-US IPO pipeline restarts, recent history offers lessons for companies, investors, and regulators.

episodes.title: Five steps to better relations between CFOs and CMOs
episodes.summary: The application of data analytics offers a useful approach to build more collaboration in support of stronger growth.

episodes.title: Unearthing the sources of value hiding in your corporate portfolio
episodes.summary: Executives who rely on high-level metrics to manage will miss potential sources of value creation. A finer-grained look can help.

episodes.title: Building a better income statement
episodes.summary: Income statements aren’t as transparent a disclosure of revenues and expenses as investors would like. Here’s a modest proposal that would address the problem.

episodes.title: What’s next for the restructuring of Europe’s banks?
episodes.summary: The long period of stagnation is over, and European banks are increasingly undergoing restructuring.

episodes.title: M&A as competitive advantage
episodes.summary: Treating M&A as a strategic capability can give companies an edge that their peers will struggle to replicate.

episodes.title: Three steps to a more productive earnings call
episodes.summary:
Traditional earnings calls are painfully unhelpful. Here’s how companies and
investors alike can get more out of them.

episodes.title: Managing the people side of risk
episodes.summary: Companies can create a powerful risk culture without turning the organization upside down.

episodes.title: Due diligence in China: Art, science, and self-defense
episodes.summary: Widespread delisating of Chinese companies has investors rethinking due diligence and looking harder for subtle clues that something is amiss.

episodes.title: Whither the US equity markets?
episodes.summary: The underlying drivers of performance suggest that over the long term, a dramatic decline in equity returns is unlikely.

episodes.title: Avoiding the consensus earnings trap
episodes.summary: The promise of meeting or beating consensus estimates and the peril of missing them are profoundly overstated.

episodes.title: Overcoming a bias against risk
episodes.summary: Midlevel managers making routine investment decisions are often too risk averse. In aggregate, they can shift an entire company’s risk profile. Promoting an organization-wide attitude toward risk can help.

episodes.title: Avoiding a risk premium that unnecessarily kills your project
episodes.summary: Too high a discount rate can make good projects seem unattractive. How high is too high?

episodes.title: The power of an independent corporate center
episodes.summary: To develop a winning corporate strategy, you may need more muscle in your headquarters.

episodes.title: How to put your money where your strategy is
episodes.summary: Allocating resources the same way every year creates inertia. Here’s a better way.

episodes.title: Choosing where to list your company
episodes.summary: Location matter matters less than the non-financial benefits an exchange offers.

episodes.title: Testing the limits of diversification
episodes.summary: It works if a company is the best owner of businesses outside its core industry.

episodes.title: Taking a longer-term look at M&A value creation
episodes.summary: Companies that do many small deals can outperform their peers—if they have the right skills. But they need more than skill to succeed in large deals.

episodes.title: Five steps to a more effective global treasury
episodes.summary: Demands on the corporate treasurer are changing, and many are struggling to keep up. Here’s where to start.

episodes.title: A bias against investment?
episodes.summary: Companies should be investing to improve their performance and set the stage for growth. They’re not.  A survey of executives suggests behavioral bias is a culprit.

episodes.title: Finding the courage to shrink
episodes.summary: Spinning off businesses can have real advantages in creating value—if executives understand how.

episodes.title: When big acquisitions pay off
episodes.summary: Some are quietly creating value that doesn’t make the headlines. Here’s how.

episodes.title: Can Chinese companies live up to investor expectations?
episodes.summary: In a reversal of long-term trends, Chinese companies now enjoy a valuation premium over their peers in developed markets. What’s changed?

episodes.title: Paying back your shareholders
episodes.summary: Successful companies inevitably face that prospect. The only real question is how.

episodes.title: Leasing: Changing accounting rules shouldn’t mean changing strategy
episodes.summary: Recent proposals will mean more transparency for investors—but won’t change how companies operate and create value.

episodes.title: How CFOs can keep strategic decisions on track
episodes.summary: The finance chief is often well placed to guard against common decision-making biases.

episodes.title: How the growth of emerging markets will strain global finance
episodes.summary: Surging demand for capital, led by developing economies, could put upward pressure on interest rates and crowd out some investment.

episodes.title: The myth of smooth earnings
episodes.summary: Many executives strive for stable earnings growth, but research shows that investors don’t worry about variability.

episodes.title: What's next for interest rates?
episodes.summary: Investment in emerging market real estate and infrastructure will drive them higher.

episodes.title: The CEO’s guide to corporate finance
episodes.summary: Four principles can help you make great financial decisions—even when the CFO’s not in the room.

episodes.title: Why Asia’s banks underperform at M&A
episodes.summary: Why do Asian banks create less value with acquisitions than nonbank investors do?

episodes.title: Conversations with global leaders: The Carlyle Group's David Rubenstein
episodes.summary: China’s role in a rebalancing global economy, the private-equity industry, and M&A.

episodes.title: The right way to hedge
episodes.summary: Deciding how to hedge requires a company-wide look at costs and benefits.

episodes.title: Five ways CFOs can make cost cuts stick
episodes.summary: Successes in cost cutting erode with time. Here’s how to make them last.

episodes.title: A singular moment for merger value?
episodes.summary: Companies have a rare chance to re-establish acquisitions as a powerful strategic tool.

episodes.title: How inflation can destroy shareholder value
episodes.summary: Executives should note that the capital markets don't expect them to deliver against longer-term analyst growth forecasts. An update of McKinsey analysis confirms that despite rules and regulations intended to improve them, equity analysts are typically still excessively optimistic. Capital markets, on the other hand, are much more reasonable in their expectations.

episodes.title: A lighter touch for postmerger integration
episodes.summary: Some Asian companies take a different approach to M&A outside their borders.

episodes.title: Deleveraging: What policymakers and executives need to know
episodes.summary:
Several major economies are likely to face imminent deleveraging. If history is any guide, it will be a lengthy and painful process

.

episodes.title: M&A teams: When small is beautiful
episodes.summary: Large M&A departments aren’t essential for making successful acquisitions.

episodes.title: Is there a better owner for your business?
episodes.summary: Companies must know how they add more value than other potential owners.

episodes.title: Risk cascades
episodes.summary:
The financial crisis provided a valuable reminder that risks gone bad in one part of the economy can set off chain reactions in areas that may seem completely unrelated. Organizations that thought they had a handle on risk management are no longer certain of their ability to anticipate the effects, both positive and negative, of events that occur throughout the business cycle.

There’s no easy formula for anticipating the path of risk as it cascades through a company or an economy. But we’ve found that executives who systematically examine the way risks propagate across their value chain—including competitors, suppliers, distribution channels, and customers—can foresee and prepare for indirect threats more successfully.

In this podcast recorded in October 2009, McKinsey Director Eric Lamarre discusses ways indirect risks can unexpectedly impact a company across the value chain.  A related article, Risk:  Seeing Around the Corners, can be found at www.mckinsey.com.

episodes.title: Unleashing the Chinese consumer
episodes.summary: A more consumer-centric Chinese economy would generate more jobs, spread the benefits of growth more equitably, and even grow more rapidly. Global companies should take note.

episodes.title: Measuring what matters in CSR programs
episodes.summary: When McKinsey consultant Sheila Bonini examined in 2007 how mainstream investors viewed corporate social responsibility programs, she found a critical shortcoming: companies typically measure only their environmental, social, or governance impact—not their financial impact, which may be significant. In this August 2009 interview with McKinsey on Finance editor Dennis Swinford, Ms. Bonini describes her research and explains how a financial evaluation offers investors a clearer, more complete picture of a company’s overall performance and helps the company to prioritize its programs and to ameliorate deep-seated social and environmental challenges. Copyright ©2009 McKinsey&Company. All rights reserved.

episodes.title: The future of private equity
episodes.summary: These funds face a credit-constrained world; they must adapt to thrive.

episodes.title: Just-in-time budgeting for a volatile economy
episodes.summary: A volatile economy makes traditional budgets obsolete before they’re even completed. Here’s how companies can adapt more quickly.

episodes.title: The crisis: Timing strategic moves
episodes.summary: Timing is key as companies weigh whether to make strategic investments now or wait for clear signs of recovery. The authors of this month’s podcast analyzed various scenarios of recovery to expose the risks of moving too quickly or slowly.

episodes.title: Financial crises, past and present
episodes.summary: Past financial crises had very different effects on the real economy. Though the lessons of the past don’t give much cause for optimism, they do provide hints on how companies should prepare this time around.

episodes.title: The CFO’s role in navigating the downturn
episodes.summary: Companies—and their CFOs—may have to adapt more radically to the downturn than they now expect.

episodes.title: Mapping decline and recovery across sectors
episodes.summary: Different sectors enter and emerge from downturns at different times. A look at past recessions suggests how some industries may fare.

episodes.title: Why the crisis hasn’t shaken the cost of capital
episodes.summary: The cost of capital hasn’t increased so far in the downturn—and didn’t in past recessions.

episodes.title: How climate change could affect corporate valuations
episodes.summary: Efforts to lower carbon emissions will affect different industries differently, depending on the level of carbon reduction required, industry responses to emerging technologies, changing customer behaviors, and regulation, and individual company current positioning and ability to respond. Executives should take steps immediately in order to be competitive in a low-carbon future.

episodes.title: Preparing for the next downturn
episodes.summary: In our April 2007 podcast, Preparing for the next downturn, the authors looked at what capabilities and strategies enabled companies to endure—and even thrive—in past downturns.The text of this recording can be found at www.mckinseyquarterly.com.

episodes.title: Preparing for a slump in earnings
episodes.summary: In our April 2008 podcast, Preparing for a slump in earnings, the authors observed that historic trends suggest earnings may fall more than most executives expect. Companies should prepare for steeper declines and take steps to strengthen their positions when times improve.  The text of this recording can be found at www.mckinseyquarterly.com.

episodes.title: A better way to understand TRS
episodes.summary: Traditional methods of analyzing TRS are flawed. There’s a better way.

episodes.title: Managing capital projects: Lessons from Asia
episodes.summary: Some Asian companies are better at executing capital projects than are rivals elsewhere. What lessons can others learn from them?

episodes.title: Organizing for value
episodes.summary: The division structure can mask big differences in the performance of smaller units. A finer-grained approach can better show where value comes from.

episodes.title: China's track record in M&A
episodes.summary: China’s companies are expanding the focus of their outbound M&A, but so far they have struggled to create value.

episodes.title: Communicating with the right investors
episodes.summary: Communicating with investors can take up a lot of an executive’s time. In our May 2008 podcast, the authors observe that executives spend too much time talking with those who don’t matter—and offer a prescription for identifying those who do.  The text of this recording can be found at www.mckinseyquarterly.com.

episodes.title: Preparing for a slump in earnings
episodes.summary: In our April 2008 podcast, Preparing for a slump in earnings, the authors observe that historic trends suggest earnings may fall more than most executives expect. Companies should prepare for steeper declines and take steps to strengthen their positions when times improve.  The text of this recording can be found at www.mckinseyquarterly.com.

episodes.title: Running a winning M&A shop
episodes.summary: The authors argue that picking up the pace of M&A requires big changes in a company’s processes and organization—even if the deals are smaller.  The text of this recording can be found at www.mckinseyquarterly.com.

episodes.title: Taking stock: Ten years after the Asian financial crisis
episodes.summary: This article is adapted from a speech given by the author in the summer of 2007 at a conference at the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco.  The text of this recording can be found at www.mckinseyquarterly.com.

episodes.title: Is the M&A boom over?
episodes.summary: Our data finds that reports of the demise of the M&A boom may be greatly exaggerated. But to keep it going, companies must work even harder to ensure that deals create value.

episodes.title: The new role of oil wealth in the world economy
episodes.summary: Regulators may worry when Arab investors acquire stakes in western companies, yet vast reserves of petrodollars have kept down interest rates and buoyed financial assets. What's the broader effect of the surge in petrodollars?

episodes.title: How to improve strategic planning
episodes.summary: It can be a frustrating exercise, but there are ways to increase its value.

episodes.title: Market fundamentals: 2000 versus 2007
episodes.summary: When the S&P 500 stretched above 1,500 in May 2007, it returned to levels not seen since the tech bubble in 2000. While it has since subsided, at this writing it is still quite strong.

episodes.title: How to choose between growth and ROIC
episodes.summary: Investors reward high-performing companies that shift their strategic focus prudently — even if that means lower returns or slower growth.

episodes.title: The granularity of growth
episodes.summary: A fine-grained approach to growth is essential for making the right choices about where to compete.

episodes.title: The state of the corporate board, 2007: A McKinsey Global Survey
episodes.summary: Corporate directors want more information about their companies and industries, and they say that investments by private-equity firms improve governance.

episodes.title: Preempting a hostile takeover
episodes.summary: Companies that stick to valuation basics can preemptively capture any value that would make them attractive for takeover bids.

episodes.title: A Quiet revolution in China’s capital markets
episodes.summary: Reforms that attracted little attention in the Western world mark a major step forward in the modernization of China’s capital markets.

episodes.title: Living with the limitations of success
episodes.summary: Once companies reach a certain size, setting realistic performance aspirations gets a bit trickier.

episodes.title: Getting more out of offshoring the finance function
episodes.summary: Companies aren’t getting the most out of their offshoring programs. Key design changes would help.

episodes.title: Preparing for the next downturn
episodes.summary: In a buoyant economy, the next recession seems far off. But managers who prepare during good times can improve their companies’ chances to endure—or thrive in—the eventual downturn.

episodes.title: The new dynamics of managing the corporate portfolio
episodes.summary: As investors demand that companies actively manage their business portfolios, executives must increasingly balance investment opportunities against the capital that’s available to finance them.

episodes.title: Why accounting rules shouldn’t drive strategy
episodes.summary: When changes in accounting rules provide no new information, they don’t register with investors. Nor should they lead managers to shift focus.

episodes.title: The truth about growth and value stocks
episodes.summary: Investors and fund managers build entire portfolios around the premise that growth stocks grow faster than value stocks. The problem is that they don’t.

episodes.title: Successful mergers start at the top
episodes.summary: A cohesive top-management team is essential for integrating acquisitions successfully.

episodes.title: When should CFOs take the helm?
episodes.summary: CFOs can bring much-needed skills to the CEO role, but the career path isn’t always a direct one.

episodes.title: Making capital structure support strategy
episodes.summary: A company’s ratio of debt to equity should support its business strategy, not help it pursue tax breaks. Here’s how to get the balance right.

episodes.title: Shaping strategy from the boardroom
episodes.summary: As companies turn their attention from compliance to growth and innovation, boards must focus on strategy.

episodes.title: A long-term look at ROIC
episodes.summary: Finance theory isn’t enough when companies set their expectations for reasonable returns on invested capital. A long-term analysis of market and industry trends can help.

episodes.title: Are companies getting better at M&A?
episodes.summary: The latest boom in merger activity appears to be creating more value for the shareholders of the acquiring companies.

episodes.title: How to make M&A work in China
episodes.summary: The conditions are right for China’s nascent M&A market to flourish. Companies should try a new approach to deal making.

episodes.title: Capital discipline for Big Oil
episodes.summary: The oil and gas industry has a history of over investing at the top of a cycle. This time it should break the habit.

episodes.title: Do fundamentals—or emotions—drive the stock market?
episodes.summary: Emotions can drive market behavior in a few short-lived situations. But fundamentals still rule.

episodes.title: Measuring long-term performance
episodes.summary: Earnings per share and share prices aren’t the whole story—particularly in the medium and long term.

episodes.title: Measuring stock market performance
episodes.summary: TRS doesn’t reflect a company’s performance or health. What does?

episodes.title: The irrational component of your stock price
episodes.summary: In the short term, emotions influence market pricing. A simple model explains short-term deviations from fundamentals.

episodes.title: Habits of the busiest acquirers
episodes.summary: M&A executives at the most successful US companies understand not only how acquisitions create value but also how to enlist the support of the organization.

episodes.title: Building the healthy corporation
episodes.summary: It is difficult—but vital—for managers to strike a balance between the short and long terms.

episodes.title: The right passage to India
episodes.summary: Companies attracted to the country’s potential must do more than merely transplant products and systems that have succeeded elsewhere.

episodes.title: Does scale matter to capital markets?
episodes.summary: Simply getting bigger won't produce a higher valuation multiple.

episodes.title: How to escape the short-term trap
episodes.summary: Markets may expect solid performance over the short term, but they also value sustained performance over the long term. How can companies manage both time frames?

episodes.title: Learning to let go: Making better exit decisions
episodes.summary: Psychological biases can make it difficult to get out of an ailing business.

episodes.title: Toward a leaner finance department
episodes.summary: Borrowing key principles from lean manufacturing can help the finance function to eliminate waste.

episodes.title: Reducing the risks of early merger discussions
episodes.summary: Used early in negotiations, a third-party clean team can help companies assess a deal and protect sensitive data.

episodes.title: Smoothing postmerger integration
episodes.summary: It takes less time than you think for a clean team to make valuable contributions to the integration of businesses.

episodes.title: The misguided practice of earnings guidance
episodes.summary: Companies provide earnings guidance with a variety of expectations and most of them don't hold up.

episodes.title: The value of share buybacks
episodes.summary: Companies shouldn't confuse the value created by returning cash to shareholders with the value created by actual operational improvements. After all, the market doesn't.

episodes.title: All P/Es are not created equal
episodes.summary: High price-to-earnings ratios are about more than growth. Understanding the ingredients that go into a strong multiple can help executives make the most of this strategic tool.
